children.subject: I also know that at least one other filled out that same form for the same class for the same semester (spring 2021).
This form doesn't have to be just for an appeal. I can express any concerns I have.
Link to appeal form: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSc4NYHdUJ8IzYA1SoiTinWBybGWkj0mfmdnHAeygAxkZajelQ/viewform

history.content: The appeals form says: "Decisions for appeal, exception, and waiver requests will be made in a monthly meeting and emailed to your berkeley.edu email in 2-3 weeks."  This makes it sound like it could be as long a 7 weeks before one receives a response in the worst case depending on when the submission was made.

children.subject: Another student filled out that same form and stated the following reasons:

But those issues are the same for everyone. Grade appeals are for people who were discriminated against, harassed, or were treated extremely unfairly.

Rao has an academic freedom to decide how to grade. Grade appeals are reviewed by someone else than course staff and they can't change the grade that he gave you because you don't like the way he graded.

What that person is saying is that DSP students are disproportionately affected by stress and didn't get partial credit for some questions. He believes the all or nothing policy for some questions is unfair.

DSP students should be given accommodations (extensions, extended time, recordings,...), but they can't be graded differently than other students. If your friend feels the course staff didn't give him the accommodations that his letter mentions, you need to file a complaint with DSP program, not grade appeal.
Both of us received extra time on exams. Staff also set a lower threshold (48% or 36% raw score to get full credit depending on extra time accommodation) for homework.
Here is a Reddit post I made: https://www.reddit.com/r/berkeley/comments/o380rd/cs_70_spring_2021_grade_appeal/. I know some students disagree.
Here is a response to 61B

You can only appeal on the following grounds:

  • application of non-academic criteria, such as: considerations of race, politics, religion, sex, or other criteria not directly reflective of performance related to course requirements;
  • sexual harassment;
  • improper academic procedures that unfairly affect a student’s grade.

It seems like your reasons don't fit any. You just don't agree with your professor's grading. Your whole argument is that this was a stressful semester, so we should not be graded harshly.

It will most likely be rejected.

Without commenting on anything else, why would you assume students from previous semesters have an accurate idea of what grade you were near? Students know their own scores and overall grade, and perhaps approximate knowledge of the scores and overall grade for at most a few dozen students. In comparison, the instructor aka Satish Rao has access to the exact scores of you and every single other student in the class, so clearly he has a better look of the distribution of scores and grades. Not to mention that a previous instructor giving 45% As doesn't mean that you can complain about the current instructor giving 40% As, for example.
He claims that he follows the syllabus.

Could you elaborate on what means? If he says your grade is x% homework y% midterm z% final I'm sure that's what it actually is, but how is that relevant here? If I misunderstood what you meant by following the syllabus, please let me know.
That's all what he said to me. I am a bit suspicious and wonder how he factors my exam scores into my grade even though the class is curved.
Students based their estimations on the overall grades their friends/classmates got.

"I am a bit suspicious and wonder how he factors my exam scores into my grade even though the class is curved."

I mean for a lot of classes, curving means that you look at the composite score of the whole class and then assign grades based at least partially on relative performance instead of solely on absolute performance. I don't see what's suspicious about that.

"Students based their estimations on the overall grades their friends/classmates got."

Yes exactly, in this case of course students will have limited and/or imperfect information and so once again I wonder why you think their opinion is relevant when the instructor himself has told you that you were relatively far away from the nearest grade boundary.
Well it's possible that he could have calculated grades incorrectly.

I understand that declaring CS can be stressful and the whole appeal process itself adds another layer of stress, but that shouldn't translate to suggesting a professor/course staff incorrectly calculated grades simply because your friends thought you'd get a higher grade than you did based on their experiences in past semesters. It would be another matter if you had a friend taking the class the same semester as you and they somehow had a higher grade with a lower overall score, but that doesn't seem to be the case here.
I see. My major is actually EECS.
In the meantime, I plan to do something else until I get a response.
Ah yeah you're right; I reread your post and you never specified your major, that's on me for making assumptions

Maybe regrades brought my final exam z-score down. That's why he said I am far away from the grade boundary. He said that he recalculated grades because of a midterm scaling issues and notified affected students a while ago.
According to him, my overall z-score is 0.56.

I also want to understand exactly how this class is graded. The syllabus states that the midterm is worth 30% of your grade and the final exam worth 40%. It does seem that the grade is based mainly on z-scores on exams since most people get 100% on homework. So I would like to get into more detail on how it is graded. Also, students predicted that I am at the border of A-, but according to the professor, I am far away from the border. I am a bit suspicious, so that is one of the main reasons for my appeal.
My main point I want to make is to ask for compensation due to Zoom issues.

history.content:
Are there any updates on my response to CS 70? I filled out the form to appeal my grade on June 17, but haven't received a response yet.

Here is a copy of my response for your convenience:

First of all in Spring 2021 CS 70, there were Zoom issues related to exams. Fifteen minutes into the exam, Zoom crashed on everyone. Therefore, everyone was given an extra 5 minutes, but most students didn't know about it since they thought they weren't allowed to check Piazza or email. If they know about it, they could have finished more problems on the exam. Just hours before the final exam, a TA (Megan) posted on Piazza to record themselves by creating their own Zoom links instead of the provided ones. Those Zoom issues caused unnecessary stress on students and I don't see any action taken by professors or course staff grade wise.

Second, during this difficult time, I wished that staff would be more lenient on grading. But they only have three hw drops, three vitamin drops, one midterm, and one final to compensate on this. Also, towards the end, some of the lectures were rushed and one topic (continuous probability) was emphasized less than previous semesters. They also introduced a new topic which wasn't covered in the previous semester. These actions may have lowered students' exam scores. While I agree that a professor cannot change a student's grade based on individual circumstances, everyone faced challenges durinf this pandemic. I understand that different classes have different grading policies, however in CS 70, the course staff didn't do much to adjust grading other than z-score grading on exams. Many students were on the border of declaring. For example, one student got a B instead of a B+, which is needed to declare as a CS major. For mu case, I thought I was on the border to get an A- based on what students who took the class before said. But according to professor Rao, I am far away from the border. This indicates that the class may have been graded harsher than before, which is not fair because all students including international and DSP students faced a lot of struggles to adapt with remote learning. It is possible that my final exam z-score may have dropped because of regrades on the final exam which could put me at an overall grade of B+.

Third, professor Rao said that they need to read the notes closely to understand the material well. But in the midst of remote learning, it is difficult to keep up due to responsibilities that students may have to face whether from their families or loved ones during the pandemic. As a result, I do not believe that the professor is understanding the situation of all studt, especially when international students live in countries that are hit hard due to skyrocketing COVID-19 cases.

Thus, I respectfully ask course staff to reconsider grades and take into account the circumstances that all students faced, and release grading bins for the class do that students ensure that their grades are calculated correctly and assigned fairly. Thank you very much for your consideration and I hope to hear back from you soon.
history.subject: CS 70 Spring 2021 Grade Appeal
